While guns are the primary topic, threads involving any other sort of weapons, from swords and knives to tanks and jet fighters, come up frequently as well. Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

That was Louis XIV's crux in governing. You see, as a child he was traumatized by the Fronde, which was basically a civil war where the local parliaments and nobility revolted because they didn't want to pay taxes. After defeating them and ensuring absolutism militarily, he had to maintain the peace, and his whole idea rested on creating a cult of personality around himself centered on Versailles.

The entire pomp was so absurd he convinced the nobility to fight amongst themselves over meaningless, petty, fictitious roles; for example, who had the right to greet the king in bed when he woke up. The actual important positions in government were staffed by competent people, many of whom were minor aristocrats, an exceptional few even commoners. Luxury become a symbol a of power precisely because it was superfluous, so nobles would spend less time building their wealth, and especially less time in their domains building local networks.

Normally the would, and only on certain guns (I think some bolt actions will be fine with ridiculous pressures) but something like sig’s MCX SPEAR is designed around 80kpsi chamber pressure. It’s Longer and beefier bolt lugs, probably a wider chamber/barrel extension too

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>56209266
Aluminum is easy and cheap to form, stainless steel is comically hard to form because of work hardening.
Aluminum is softer so maybe there's less wear in the gun besides it's weaker (compared to its volume) and cracks easier, so forget about reload aluminum cases.

I'd show you a photo of some brass/nickle ones I have around but you could google it just as easily. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous >>56139887
End of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

threads.com:
I will start: Storm of Steel (in German: In Stahlgewittern, lit.'In Steel Thunderstorms'; original English title: In Storms of Steel) is the memoir of German officer Ernst Jünger's experiences on the Western Front during the First World War from December 1914 to August 1918.

> The book is a graphic account of trench warfare. It was largely devoid of editorialization when first published, but was heavily revised several times. The book established Jünger's fame as a writer in the 1920s. The judgment of contemporaries and later critics reflects the ambivalence of the work, which describes the war in all its brutality, but neither expressly condemns it nor goes into its political causes. It can be read affirmatively, neutrally or as an anti-war book.

Why I recommend it: Its accurately describes how the war actually was, all the details. Very very good read.

Exactly what it says.

They added a 125mm but deleted the ammo carousel and autoloader, moved the ammo to a bustle in the rear of the turret and added a turret floor/basket for the loader.

Given the amount of space taken up by the ammo which was stored in a compartment on the rear firewall, next to the driver and on the floor there seems to enough space theoretically for the 5th crewman. It also has an elongated hull. The logical place would be next to the driver that used to be a ammo rack.

Has anyone here been inside one? If you delete the stowage and hardware can you fit a guy next to the driver?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56208409
Can confirm to a certain degree. Have a target bag full of compressed clothes for my crossbow and tried my knives on it.

Drop points, false edges, anything that didn't cut tended to reduce penetration pretty significantly.

Double edged spear point blades penetrated extremely well and the same applied to knives with straight spines (like my Moras). True clip point does better than anything with a drop point.

The two knives in the pic, my modified TOPS BOB and my Extrema Ratio Defender 2 require about the same force for pushing them into the fabric, despite the TOPS having a much larger cross-section of the blade.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Let's start a gun storage thread anons. I live with a family member who is totally arthritic and unable to handle guns in any way. Having them accessible in the home when I'm away can only be a liability for them, so I'm buying a safe. Can anyone recommend good 20 gun safes on a budget? picrel i was thinking of choosing the winchester 20 gun safe

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56206603
The Winchester brand safes are just a brand slapped on a Chinesium safe with some gypsum sandwiched between thin-ass sheet metal that anybody with a can opener can rip into. which they won't because the door can be popped open with a crowbar in about 3 seconds.

If you want a composite safe Liberty is the bare minimum but we're still only talking a few minutes for a a strong guy with a prybar to get in. A plate steel safe is what you need for actual theft protection, but that's exponentially more money and weight. Weight is a huge issue if you aren't a homeowner because moving a real safe is an absolute bitch of a process that you aren't going to want to do more than once.

If you're just trying to keep your arthritic family member from messing with it, a much lighter/cheaper thin steel cabinet is fine. It will offer pretty much zero fire or burglar protection but it will be much smaller, easier to move and cheaper. Don't bother paying by brand, just get whatever is cheap, conveniently available and adequate size.
If you are a homeowner and don't plan to move anytime soon get an actual plate steel safe. It's expensive as fuck and you'll have to budget some beers for getting everyone you know to help move it but it is worth the peace of mind once installed. You can actually get them really cheap from someone else who is moving so check classifieds like craigslist for used ones in your area first. Half the time they will practically give it away if you go to the trouble to actually move the thing.
Alternatively actual locksmith shops get used safes all the time and can have really good deals. Sometimes they even have vintage safes that are 50-100+ years old, made in America and really well built.

threads.com:
Alright, so I'm really interested in obscure, anecdotal military air confrontations and incidents, and used to read a lot of Tom Cooper, and I mean a LOT of Tom Cooper.
However, I've been noticing overtime that several incidents and anecdotes he mentions in his books and articles have the details skewed, and I wanted to go over the ones I've found for two reasons,
1. After enough of them, you start wondering about his competence and/or integrity
2. They're interesting even with accurate details. I'll provide greentexts for two of these stories with all research I've done after I detail the places he fucked up in.

First is an incident where Talibs shot down an Uzbek Su-24 Fencer.
https://web.archive.org/web/20130921144724/http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_339.shtml
In this older acig article, he says the Fencer was shot down on June 6th, 2001. However, looking for more details, I tracked down a copy of the August 2000 edition of Air Forces Monthly, and found it was June 6th/7th, 2000.
Sadly this possible typo confused the author Lukas Muller, who stated the incorrect 2001 date on page 58 of his book Wings Over the Hindu Kush: Air Forces, Aircraft and Air Warfare of Afghanistan, 1989-2001, citing Cooper's article on page 71.
